components.name: Alerts
components.description: Length: 1-2 short sentences (50-120 characters). Four types: informational (blue, 'i' icon), warning (yellow, warning icon), error (red, 'x' icon), success (green, checkmark icon). Sentence case. Clear, direct, non-alarming tone. [Action] + [Result/Impact] structure.

subtypes.name: Informational Alert
subtypes.usage: Use for neutral information, tips, or general updates. For communicating changes that don't require immediate action.
subtypes.example: A new feature has been added to your dashboard.

subtypes.name: Warning Alert
subtypes.usage: Use for potential issues that require attention but aren't critical errors. For situations that may cause problems if unaddressed.
subtypes.example: Your storage is at 90% capacity. Consider upgrading soon.

subtypes.name: Error Alert
subtypes.usage: Use for critical issues that prevent users from proceeding. For system failures, validation errors, or unsuccessful actions.
subtypes.example: Payment failed. Please check your payment details and try again.

subtypes.name: Success Alert
subtypes.usage: Use to confirm successful completion of actions. For positive feedback after user interactions.
subtypes.example: Your changes have been successfully saved.

dos: Use sentence case for all alert text
Lead with consequence or question, follow with directive, end with outcome
Use [Action] + [Result/Impact] structure
Use standard phrasing for similar alert types
Maintain consistent terminology for common actions
End complete sentences with periods
Keep between 50-120 characters
Match tone to alert type (informational vs. error)
Include next steps when relevant (e.g. 'Please try again')
Use contextual phrasing for irreversible actions ('You cannot undo this action')
Use question format for assistance options ('Have an emergency?')
Include notification references when applicable ('[Person] will be notified')
Keep tone direct and clear without being alarming
Be professional but conversational
donts: Don't use alarming or aggressive language
Don't use technical jargon unless necessary
Don't mix alert types (e.g. success message in error alert)
Don't exceed 120 characters
Don't omit the action/result structure
Don't use inconsistent terminology across similar alerts
Don't use inconsistent punctuation (keep periods at end of complete sentences)

components.name: Buttons
components.description: Length: 1-3 words (max 25 characters). Sentence case (capitalize first word only). Verb + Object format preferred. Three types: Primary (solid blue bg + white text), Secondary (white bg + visible stroke), Tertiary (no fill, text only).

subtypes.name: Primary Button
subtypes.style: Solid blue background fill + white text
subtypes.usage: The main action on a page or in a modal; the most important or most frequently used action.

subtypes.name: Secondary Button
subtypes.style: White background fill (visible stroke) + black/gray text
subtypes.usage: Alternative or supporting actions; important but not the main focus.

subtypes.name: Tertiary Button
subtypes.style: No fill (no stroke) + solely black/gray text
subtypes.usage: Supplementary actions, links, or less common options.

dos: Use sentence case (capitalize first word only)
Use Verb + Object format: 'Add new insurance', 'Send payment', 'Create workflow'
Alternative: Single verb or noun for common actions: 'Save', 'Cancel', 'Filters'
Be specific about the action: 'Upload faxes' not just 'Upload'
Use recognizable patterns ('New chat' follows the 'New + noun' pattern)
Use consistent verbs for similar actions (e.g. 'Create' not 'Make' or 'Build')
Use clear opposites for opposing actions: 'Save' / 'Cancel'
Use strong verbs for primary buttons: 'Create', 'Send', 'Save'
Use neutral verbs for secondary buttons: 'Cancel', 'Back'
Keep to 1-3 words, max 25 characters
Use '+' icon before text for creation/addition actions
Icon should reinforce, not replace, the text
All buttons can have appropriate icons
Prioritize clarity over brevity, but be as concise as possible
donts: Don't use Title Case (e.g. 'Save Changes' is wrong, use 'Save changes')
Don't use all caps
Don't use vague labels like 'Submit' when you can be specific
Don't use different verbs for the same action type
Don't exceed 25 characters
Don't use icons without accompanying text labels

components.name: Input Fields
components.description: Labels: 1-3 words, sentence case, max 25 chars. Required fields: asterisk (*) at the end. Placeholder: format examples only (max 20 chars). Helper text: below field, max 50 chars. Error pattern: 'Please enter a valid [field type]', max 40 chars. No punctuation at end.

fieldTypes.name: Standard Text Field
fieldTypes.usage: Simple text entry with label. Use for names, emails, basic text input.

fieldTypes.name: Format-Specific Field
fieldTypes.usage: Text entry with format indicators. Use for dates, phone numbers, structured inputs.

fieldTypes.name: Selection Field
fieldTypes.usage: Dropdown or selection component. Use for choosing from predefined options.

labels.length: 1-3 words, max 25 characters (including spaces and asterisk)

placeholders.purpose: To provide format guidance, not instructions
placeholders.rules: Standard text fields: no placeholder. Format-specific fields: show example format. Selection fields: use 'Select' only.
badExamples: Enter your first name... (unnecessary for standard fields)
Choose from the list. (too wordy, includes punctuation)

helperText.purpose: To provide format requirements that cannot be covered by placeholder text
helperText.position: Below the input field, above any error messages
helperText.format: No punctuation at the end for single instructions
useWhen: Format is too complex for placeholder
goodExamples: Must contain at least one number
badExamples: Your password must be secure! (not specific about format requirements)
Please be sure to include a number in your password. (too wordy)
Password requirements: 8+ characters, 1 uppercase, 1 number, 1 special character. (too many requirements for helper text)

errorTypes: Format errors: when input doesn't match required format
Missing required field: when required field is empty
goodExamples: Please enter a valid email address
Please enter a valid phone number
Please enter a valid date of birth
badExamples: Invalid email address. (incorrect pattern, includes punctuation)
Please Enter A Valid Email Address (incorrect capitalization)
Email is required! (incorrect pattern, includes punctuation)

dos: Use sentence case for labels
Place asterisk (*) at the end of required field labels
Use format examples for placeholders: 'MM/DD/YYYY', '000-000-0000'
Use 'Select' as placeholder for dropdowns
Keep error messages under 40 characters
Follow 'Please enter a valid [field]' error pattern
Keep helper text under 50 characters
Place labels above the input field
Be specific but concise ('Phone number' not just 'Phone')
Use recognizable patterns ('First name'/'Last name')
Keep placeholder text to max 20 characters
Use helper text only when format is too complex for placeholder
donts: Don't put asterisk before the label ('* Email' is wrong)
Don't use punctuation at end of labels, placeholders, or error messages
Don't use 'Enter your...' as placeholder text
Don't use Title Case for labels
Don't use wordy placeholder text ('Choose from the list.')
Don't use helper text when placeholder is sufficient
Don't use 'Invalid [field]' error pattern
Don't exceed 25 characters for labels
Don't exceed 20 characters for placeholder text
Don't use 'Email is required!' error pattern (incorrect pattern and punctuation)

components.name: Tooltips
components.description: Brief explanations (20-75 chars). Sentence case. White text on grey background. Use 'i' icon in circle for information tooltips. Key information first, then details. Supplements but does not replace essential UI text.

scopeGuidelines.note: Tooltips should supplement, not replace, essential UI text

informationHierarchy: For date/time information: action first, then who, when, where
actionGuidance: For status indicators: include next steps if applicable
For form fields: include validation requirements
For disabled elements: explain why disabled and how to enable
examples: Last eligibility run by [Staff Name] on March 17, 2025 at 3:30PM CST
dos: Keep simple tooltips to 20-40 characters
Keep complex tooltips to 40-75 characters
Put key information first (action, object, outcome)
Include next steps for status indicators
Include validation requirements for form fields
For disabled elements: explain why disabled and how to enable
Always add tooltips to icon-only buttons
Align tooltip terminology with documentation
Use consistent verbs across similar actions
Maintain consistent voice across the application
For date/time: action first, then who, when, where
donts: Don't use tooltips for multi-step processes (use inline help)
Don't use tooltips to replace essential UI text
Don't exceed 75 characters
Don't omit tooltips on icon-only buttons
Don't use inconsistent terminology

components.name: Settings
components.description: Setting name: 3-7 words, Title Case, clear and action-oriented. Description: 1-2 sentences, sentence case, direct language. Professional, informative, slightly technical when necessary.

formatTypes.name: Toggle Settings
formatTypes.example: Enable this setting to hide messages in Hub and Patient Profile from users who shouldn't have access based on their provisioning.

formatTypes.name: Selection Settings
formatTypes.pattern: Select whether [object] in [location] should [action A] or [action B].
formatTypes.example: Should new messages in the Collaboration Hub or Patient Profile be secure or non-secure text by default?

formatTypes.name: Information Fields
formatTypes.example: If using Luma Health's web-based referral form, send this form link to your referring providers.

formatTypes.name: Numeric Settings
formatTypes.example: What is the maximum number of times that Luma Health should attempt to contact a patient about an inbound referral?

dos: Use Title Case for setting names
Use sentence case for descriptions
Follow toggle format: 'Enable this setting to [action]...'
Follow selection format: 'Select whether [object] should...'
Follow information field format: 'If using [feature], [instruction]...'
Follow numeric format: 'What is the [quantity measure] of [action]?'
Keep descriptions to 1-2 sentences
Be specific about the setting's effect and location
Keep setting names to 3-7 words
Be clear and action-oriented in naming
donts: Don't use vague setting names
Don't omit the benefit/impact in descriptions
Don't use technical jargon in descriptions
Don't use more than 7 words for setting names
Don't use sentence case for setting names (use Title Case)

components.name: Table Headers
components.description: Length: 1-2 words (max 20 chars). Title Case. Neutral, descriptive tone. Noun or short noun phrase.
dos: Use Title Case for all column headers
Keep to 1-2 words maximum
Use nouns or short noun phrases
Stay under 20 characters
Examples: 'Title', 'Patients', 'Status', 'Delivery Time', 'Created', 'Specialty', 'Confidence', 'Received', 'Facility', 'Type'
donts: Don't use sentence case for table headers
Don't use verbs in column headers
Don't exceed 20 characters
Don't use abbreviations without established convention

components.name: Statuses
components.description: Use sentence case for all status indicators (e.g., 'In progress', 'Pending review', 'Completed').
dos: Use sentence case: 'In progress', 'Pending review', 'Completed'
Be consistent across the product
Use clear, recognizable status labels
donts: Don't use Title Case for statuses ('In Progress' is wrong)
Don't use all caps
Don't use technical or ambiguous status labels

components.name: Modals
components.description: Title: 2-5 words, sentence case. Body: 1-3 sentences, sentence case. Confirmation/warning modals typically use 'Are you sure?' title. Include 'This cannot be undone' for destructive/irreversible actions. Primary button should match the title question.

subtypes.name: Deletion Modal
subtypes.title: Delete [Item Name]? or Delete the [item type] '[item name]'?
subtypes.body: This cannot be undone. / This action will permanently remove [item] and all associated data. This cannot be undone.
subtypes.example: Title: 'Delete the checklist "New patient"?' Body: 'This cannot be undone.'

subtypes.name: Confirmation Modal
subtypes.title: Are you sure?
subtypes.body: Clearly state what will happen when the action is confirmed.
subtypes.example: Title: 'Are you sure?' Body: 'Deleting this workflow will permanently remove this and any data related to it.'

subtypes.name: Warning Modal
subtypes.title: Are you sure? or Warning
subtypes.body: Explain consequences and include 'This action cannot be undone' for irreversible actions.
subtypes.example: Title: 'Are you sure?' Body: 'Please review carefully to ensure accuracy before proceeding. Splitting this fax will create new faxes in the defined groups. This action cannot be undone.'

subtypes.name: Archive Modal
subtypes.title: Are you sure?
subtypes.body: Archiving this [item] will remove it from [location/system]. This cannot be reversed.
subtypes.example: Title: 'Are you sure?' Body: 'Archiving this fax will remove it from Fax Transform. This cannot be reversed.'

subtypes.name: Information Modal
subtypes.title: Brief description of information being presented
subtypes.body: 1-2 sentences with necessary details or instructions.
subtypes.example: Title: 'System Maintenance' Body: 'Luma will be unavailable on Sunday, May 12 from 2-4am ET for scheduled maintenance.'

subtypes.name: Success Modal
subtypes.title: Success or specific action completed
subtypes.body: Confirmation of completed action and any next steps.
subtypes.example: Title: 'Workflow Created' Body: 'Your new workflow has been successfully created and is now active.'

dos: Use 'Are you sure?' for confirmation, warning, and archive modals
Include 'This cannot be undone' or 'This cannot be reversed' for irreversible/destructive actions
Match button copy to title: 'Are you sure?' â†’ 'I'm sure'
If the modal title is a question, the button copy should answer it
Reference the specific item being affected (checklist, workflow, fax)
Use sentence case for titles and body text
Keep titles to 2-5 words
Deletion title: 'Delete [Item Name]?' or 'Delete the [type] "[name]"?'
Success title: specific action completed (e.g. 'Workflow Created')
Keep body text to 1-3 sentences
Clearly state consequences in confirmation modals
donts: Don't use vague body text that doesn't explain consequences
Don't forget 'This cannot be undone' for destructive actions
Don't use generic button labels that don't match the action
Don't use Title Case for modal titles
Don't exceed 3 sentences in body text
Don't omit the specific item being affected

components.name: Descriptive/General Copy
components.description: Flexible length (typically 1-3 sentences per concept). Sentence case. Conversational but professional tone. Clear explanations with occasional brand personality. Active voice. Second person ('you'). Clarity first, positive framing.
dos: Use sentence case everywhere except Title Case where specified
Use active voice when describing actions
Use second person ('you') when addressing the user
Prioritize clarity over cleverness
Focus on what users can do (positive framing)
Use 'zip code' (not 'Post code' or 'Postal code')
Remove unnecessary words while maintaining clarity
Be professional yet approachable, expert but not jargony
Keep to 1-3 sentences per concept typically
donts: Don't use passive voice for user actions
Don't use first person ('we', 'I')
Don't use jargon or overly technical language
Don't be clever at the expense of clarity
Don't focus on limitations (use positive framing instead)
Don't use 'Post code' or 'Postal code' (use 'zip code')
